Award.AwardTitle: Chemical Self-Enrichment in the Nearest OB Association
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Mamajek and his team will conduct an observational program to characterize variations in the chemical abundances among young stars in the Scorpius-Centaurus complex, a relatively nearby region of star formation. The principal goal of the effort will be to see if, when star formation began, a few supernovae exploded and altered the abundances in the gas out of which stars were later formed; in this case, there might be variations from place to place in the abundances of elements in stars we see today. The elements chosen for study are sensitive tracers of the mass of the progenitor stars of the supernovae.

It is anticipated that results of the investigation may give insights into the process of star formation in general and of the solar system in particular. The team also plans to create and distribute animations depicting star formation and the history of the Scorpius-Centaurus complex.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principle aims of this award were to observationally study the star formation history, chemical enrichment and heterogeneity within the nearest site of recent massive star-formation (Sco-Cen OB association) in order to determine the degree to which core-collapse supernovae enrich the chemical abundances of the later generations of star-formation. The signatures of short-lived radioactive nuclides in meteorites – most likely from supernovae - suggest that our solar system probably formed in a star-forming complex similar to Sco-Cen over 4 billion years ago. The Sco-Cen association contains thousands of young stars with ages of <20 million years and distances of ~300-600 light years situated in the southern skies (constellations Scorpius, Lupus, Centaurus, and Crux). Sco-Cen provides a valuable testbed for understanding the formation and early evolution of stars and planetary systems.

Chemical abundances of several key elements were determined using high-resolution optical spectra of Sun-like stars in Sco-Cen, and quantified using the MOOG analysis package. Considerable effort went into deriving consistent oxygen abundances (a useful proxy to represent supernova enrichment) through both standard spectroscopic abundance analyses and spectral synthesis. Young stars have large cool starspots and hot plage regions which complicate their spectra, producing systematic trends in temperature vs. chemical abundance. So far, our results show that the young stars in Sco-Cen have chemical composition fairly similar to that of our Sun, and that the chemical compositions amongst the three major Sco-Cen subgroups are statistically indistinguishable. This suggests that the degree of chemical self-enrichment in the groups due to core-collapse supernovae is fairly inefficient.

Some notable discoveries were made during the course of this project:

First, in the course of discovering and characterizing new young Sun-like stars in the Sco-Cen association, we discovered the first transiting extrasolar ring system, dubbed a “Super Saturn”. Follow-up investigations have constrained that the mass of the ringed object makes it either a young giant planet or brown dwarf. This ringed companion (“J1407b”) may be the first observed example of an astrophysical object long predicted by theorists: a circumplanetary disk in the process of forming moons. We project that in the course of its survey monitoring the southern skies, the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) project will probably uncover several new examples of J1407b-like objects, opening up a new subfield of exoplanetary science: observational studies of exosatellite formation.

Second, we discovered that the Upper Scorpius subgroup (one of the best-studied samples of young stars for understanding the evolution of protoplanetary disks and imaging young giant planets) is actually twice as old as previously estimated (11 million years vs. 5 million years). This result came from a detailed comparison of the temperatures and luminosities of stars in Upper Sco compared to the latest generations of stellar evolutionary tracks. This is consistent with some other recent published results that show that some samples of young stars appear to be systematically older than previously calculated. Taken together, these results suggest that the lifetimes of protoplanetary disks are roughly twice as long as previously constrained. This has the effect of making it easier for gas giant planets to form, and alleviating some tension between planet formation models and observations.

Third, this study discovered approximately 200 new members of Sco-Cen with masses similar to our Sun and slightly lower.
